content:
I figured out the answers for more than 50% of the puzzle and i have to say it has nothing to do with the VERY HARD category. It's just guesswork. Seriously there's no achievement in solving this.
In fact the only challenge is the statement.
it should be specific what's wrong with the output, is it wrong format or just wrong answer?
This really needs a bit more explanation regarding the output format. I formatted the output in like 20 different ways. So what exactly do you actually want the output to be for ss_n?

"Big thanks to bubnet for permission!"
Apparently it's bub*m*et https://bubmet.itch.io/
It's too hard for me D:

Nice challenge while still doable with some investigations, trial and error, letting it rest and going back to it the next day when stuck :)

Minor points:

* Is the non-ASCII ¬ \u00AC character really bringing anything? It might bring some more confusion or problems with some languages (the \u syntax is not quite universal I presume). Maybe using an ASCII character instead would be better?

* Personally I got confused once by the fact that a single test uses several lock types. I did not realize I had solved the first type because the second one was failing. Given the difficulty, it would also be more encouraging to get something green each time. It's fine to have multiple locks at the end, after all types have been introduced, to check success was not accidental.

After what pac-nam wrote, I got back to the puzzle again and saw my solution for ss_asc was wrong.
it would probably be a good idea to harmonize the input data a little bit more.
1. Fill the last line of input with whitespaces for as long as the previous lines were
2. Remove the unneccessary whitespace in "6"
3. Question: What happens if the only numbers are 3, 6, 8? Is the input going to be 6 or 7 lines long? After about 50 tries, I didn't get any with only these numbers, so I cannot test this.

00:00 how can I found the solution to puzzles, if I have no clues, I'm on ss_f and this is a serie of 6 following letter 5 upper, 1 lower (can be anywhere) and i need to print an int. I tried to print the value of the lower letter, to add all ascii values, to capitalize every char, and add it... I'm out of idea.

00:15 finally, that was not the value, but the index. It could be nice to have the solution if we fail. just to have an idea of what to do, or just an interval in the statement. now... rs_f

00:45 on gs_m this time. what does "str, 2" mean. what is the output format ? "str" ok, I can figure what it is, but what is this "2" ? 2 strings (or symbol) are waited ? the number have to be printed ? and if there is 2 things to print, what is the format. Are they separated by ", " or " " or "\n". I'm sure this puzzle is awesome. But it's really frustrating to trample on (sorry for the litteral translation of french expression)

00:50 And again, what is the symbol needed ? I tried ascii, the index of the number in "Need symbol: X" (modulo the length), but no clue

01:00 (╯°□°)╯︵ ┻━┻

01:35 sorry... ┬━┬ ノ( ゜-゜ノ)
I repeat, to not be misinterpreted, the puzzle is really interesting, the structure is good and the challenge is in the restricted information. just let me get mad about this frustrating #@!#?#@. If you like headache, it's for you. Anyway I upvoted it, and I will continue to tear off my hair to find my own solution (can be a good teamwork :D).

01:45 I'll continue to tell my (boring) story. I'm still on gs_m. I tried to print the symbol of the number (always +) and ", 2". So I printed "+, 2". Surprisingly, it didn't work. Also print the number (modulo 26) as the index in alphabet, lower and upper case, separated by " "|","|", "|"\n"|"" and then upper and lower. Didn't work too. Ascii don't work.
Next idea: On my way to find one

01:55 let's think, the test is named lookup table. It's probably not the ascii table. So which other conversion table from int to string/char does exist ?

02:10 thanks Fluttershy for the help. So the answer is an Uppercase and a lowercase (lowercase can be missing) not separated

02:25 Fluttershy was right...
ノ┬─┬ノ ︵ ( o°o)

03:00 still didn't give up

03:10 fu** it I'm out... I will do the others tests then come back to gs_m/ss_m

03:30 I finally finished the conversion table from ascii art. How will I implement it now? Split by space columns seems good, but it will cause problems with 6 and 8. Thinking time.

03:32 and I'm on ss_asc

03:40 Maybe I found a mistake in the puzzle. To the end of the last line in ascii art, spaces are removed. It can be hard to deal with it in many languages, because, the concversion table have spaces. To pass through I only use the 3 first lines of each number. But it's just a trick

04:00 Ascii finished :D to deal with the missing spaces, I just added the difference of spaces from first to last line. But I still think only the 3 first lines of numbers can be used (confirmed by test).

ss_con-lock doesn't have it's timeout anymore and takes longer to get to the end. 60 iterations of outputting "0" gives an exception that the game takes too long.
java.lang.RuntimeException: Total game duration too long (>30000ms)
(It previously terminated after about 80 rounds)

The problem with this is that when "trying out things" you will now always run into an exception, not even getting your debug output.

My previous submission broke. You can view it here: https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/4289b5a61790732bd4ce988be65ef8439cb8

I've changed the test cases significantly. The locks are the same, but now similar ones are grouped together under one test case.

- Fixed double output needed to fail
- Removed unused lock
- Added attribution

Thoughts:
- Unrandomize the test case solutions
- Bump difficulty to Very Hard if not enough people can figure this out.
- Blinking cursor to complete the 80's hacker effect

It appears a fix I put in for the gs_m lock broke ss_con. It now catches its own internal exception instead of letting it rise to the Referee so the game can be ended. 

Gonna put out a fix when I get home tonight or if I can use a computer today.
I would suggest trying the next test case, you will probably be flipping tables again, then.

1. I thought I did :thinking:
2. Due to the way I generate the numbers, the arrays that represent the numbers are all the same size. Since 6 is smaller than the others, it gets padded to make the array size match.
3. You get a line filled with spaces (you will always get 6 lines)
Oh snap.

I disagree. What you call guessing, I -- and the author -- call reverse engineering, and it's the point of the puzzle. Don't expect the statement to give you clues about the answers (including the format), and don't torture yourself to finish the puzzle if you don't like it. It is indeed quite different from most other puzzles here, and I think the added variety is a good thing.

How can you compare this to reverse engineering and how exactly am i torturing myself? To guess the #4 i had to run it few times without doing anything and then look at the input. The test cases don't even follow a topic and they aren't related.

#3 and #4 are clear proof of what i am talking about. Guesswork.

#2 was also nothing other than guess work, initially one might think it's something more complicated. I guess you need to expect less then it's easier to guess.

#5 isn't even a spoiler if i talk about it, that's NOT reverse engineering. Please. It's not even guesswork!

#6 this one maybe has less to do with guessing and more with reverse-engineering the pattern

#7 guesswork

#8 mix and match the guess criteria

#9 not sure - didn't spend more than a minute on it tbh

Where do you see reverse engineering? Honestly might as well do a similar puzzle with fairy tale topics and have people guess that. The difference would be the testcases follow something specific.

Also would much rather have this in the medium category, next to the fake mobius strip puzzle and give this puzzle a more helpful error message.

Also my initial frustration came from the fact that i slightly miscounted the required steps for the #1 and the error message and confusing statement just made me believe i need a different approach. It was nothing other than annoying.

And my suggestion would be to do something more in line with CG reverse engineering puzzle, UTG or OOC. It still has a good chunk of guess work in them but it follows a topic and it's okey-ish as a challenge to extract hidden info / reverse engineering enemy position and such.

CTF for example although it can get highly complicated, it follows a topic/theme.
Let's agree it's a controversial puzzle, as the votes show :)
Uploading the fix along with some other minor changes
brb making the test cases case-insensitive

The test cases are now case-insensitive. 

Warning: gs_m and ss_m will probably have you flipping pool tables

I continue here, It appear that I reached the maximal length.

04:00 5 done, 5 remaining

04:10 (ノ-_-)ノ ミ　┴┴
what the f*** is this format "series, state machine, 1". Let me guess, the serie is a colored number serie separated by "..." or "", state machine is colored "ONLINE" or "OFFLINE", 1... don't know. These 3 parts are separated by "" or " " or "," or ", "

05:00 came back to gs_m (too much possibilities on ss_con) and still don't know. I can't do any hypothesis or do trial and error. I'll retry tomorrow

Addressing 04:10:

The format is, as written under "color codes", always a "¬" followed by one character, which makes the following text a specific color. Because color often switches, it looks a little bit "heavy".
You will see how it looks like in the video.

There are no commas in there?
Example input:

2
ss_con: Unauthorized
¬b0¬r...¬R1¬r...¬R2¬r...¬R3¬r...¬R4¬r...¬R5¬r...¬VO ¬rOFFLINE
I can understand the input (I printed it), but what is waited as output ? It's what I am trying to guess
I've made the change (and tested it). Turns out it was a fix to stop my local AI from timing out on ss_asc on rare occasions.
